guide.title: Gentoo Weekly Newsletter
guide.subtitle: 15 January 2007
guide.abstract: This is the Gentoo Weekly Newsletter for the week of 15 January 2007.

p.b: The future of the bugday project.

body.p: As most of you know the bugday project is a fast growing project which helps users to get involved with gentoo (e.g. by helping them on how to fix bugs, helping each other and having fun).
The Bugdayteam is currently going through a lot of changes. They are currently going through a lot of changes which involves:

ul.li:
Bugday helpers.
This is a new term which will allow users to help out with arranging bugdays together with the team. They will receive a special bugday helper cloak for their IRC account and should be available to help fellow users at bugdays.
The helpers should be the man-in-the-middle between the bugday in our users and will later on be a key player on the idea of moving the bugday project to be completely users driven, except the infrastructure hosting.

Social Bugdays
The bugday team are going to make some documents about how to start making social bugdays in your local linux user group. The documents should describe briefly describe how to arrange the bugdays; what do you need to make sure you have and so on.

body.p: If you would like to contribute, join them on irc at their channel irc://irc.freenode.org/#gentoo-bugs

p.b: 64bit PS3 stage4 released to Gentoo mirrors

body.p: This week ranger wrote at his blog about the amazing work the PPC64 team is doing with Gentoo-On-PS3. They have currently made PS3-livecd with support for 64bit-userland and 32bit-userland stage4 installations (which both run an 64bit kernel). Other than that, they have 32bit and 64bit GRP online Toolchains which are maturing to take further advantage of the Cell processor. In short, it's a viable desktop machine for email, browsing, music, office work, and much more.
This week the linux conf australia is being held at Sydney. Daniel Ostrow is attending for gentoo, where he is going to hilight PS3 and Gentoo.

section.title: Belgium: Free and Open Source Developers European Meeting, Brussels

body.p: Like the last few years, Gentoo will be presently at fosdem. This year with even a greater amount of developers than ever before. We're glad to present you the following schedule for our dev-room:
body.pre: 14:00 -> 14:30 :: Welcome Dimitry Bradt (diox) 14.30 -> 16.00 :: Gentoo Hardened - the hardened toolchain and the security perspective of the Gentoo Linux distribution Alexander Gabert (pappy-) 16.00 -> 17.00 :: Introduction to SELinux Bryan Øtergaard (kloeri) 17.00 -> 18.00 :: Gentoo/Alt:Prefix Project Fabian Groffen (grobian) 18.00 -> 18.45 :: General Discussion to gentoo's future All Developers

09:30 -> 10.00 :: The future of the Bugday project Alexander Færøy (eroyf) 10.00 -> 11.00 :: Programming with Paludis Danny van Dyk (Kugelfang) 11.00 -> 12.00 :: Gentoo's inner working: The Council Mike Frysinger (vapier) 12.00 -> 13.00 :: Release Engineering: Tinderbox testing Chris Gianelloni (wolf31o2) 13.00 -> 14.00 :: Noon Break ** (Closed door debate) 14.00 -> 15.00 :: What makes Gentoo a community based distribution? Christel Dahlskjaer (christel) 15.00 -> 16.00 :: The portage Marius Mauch (genone) 16.00 -> 17.00 :: Java Joshua Nichols (nichoj)
body.p: Not only will we give talks in the dev-room, but we're also available with a large group at the booths. That's right, prepare your questions ;-).
So mark Fosdem at 24 and 25 February in your diary&s. We're all very excided to present you our latest releases. For more information check their website.

Dutch Documentation Lead Dimitry Bradt and other members of the Dutch community have organised a LAN party last weekend to celebrate the start of the new year. Because the location itself was between Antwerpen and Eindhoven (right at the border), a lot of people joined up the dutch conspiracy. At the lan they enjoyed Quake3, worms3d and weird enough ksudoku. Other than that they've written an interface to control the sound system there, and off course drank a lot of belgian beers.
Among the visitors, there was an international guest present, namely: Gentoo developer Alexander Buisse. His impressions after the event also went to the good belgian beer.
You can find some pictures at their photoalbum. See you all at Fosdem ;-).
